results.title: Assault on the Land
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
Examines the problems of salinity, showing how it affects not only the farmers, but all of us. Several methods currently in use to combat the problems are examined in areas of Victoria.

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: interactive software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]

results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection 2]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring elements on ‘how a movie is made’ and a split screen collage of moving images, interspersed with intertitles. The work was initially designed as part of a fundraising campaign.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Australian Dried Fruits Association; John Richardson; Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Ivan Gaal; Wine Australia and Tony Agapitos.

results.title: 50 years of cardiology
results.brief_description: Working in cardiology for many years, Graeme Sloman explains the many achievements he and his fellow colleagues have made in preventing heart disease-related fatalities and building a greater public awareness of heart disease. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: How to kill your husband
results.brief_description: Shirley’s father, a skilled mechanic and excellent drummer, suffered from heart disease. Shirley retells her father’s history, from the struggles of growing up during the depression to his now proud children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: [Compilation. No. 01]
results.brief_description: A compilation of three short silent films featuring newsreel footage on the following: 1. Charles Lindbergh’s triumphant public receptions after his Transatlantic flight - in Paris, Brussels, London, Washington DC and New York. Presentation by President Coolidge of Distinguished Flying Cross (Kinnogram Films). 2. Footage of koalas with explanatory intertitles (Kodak Australia). 3. Footage of kangaroos, wallabies, bandicoots etc with explanatory intertitles (Development and Migration Commission).

results.title: Lease of life
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Presents the Victorian Cancer Institute’s 4MeV linear accelerator. An important weapon against cancer, it is used for deep X-ray therapy. Traces a case history of a woman who is eventually restored to her family by the special treatment made possible by the accelerator. Narrated by Marcia Hart. Filmed at the Peter MacCallum Cancer Institute in Melbourne, Victoria.

results.title: [Vacuum review. No. 2]
results.brief_description: Promotional documentary from around 1939 sponsored by the Vacuum Oil Company showing how Vacuum Oil lubricants are used in machinery including agricultural machinery, machinery used in the gold mining industry, a car body building plant machinery, earth moving equipment, cars and motorcycles. Title missing and no credits available.

results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Television and United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.
